terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Alberta prairie. Moderate elevation with prairie scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional Alberta event. Prairie terrain with moderate access, moderate costs, and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Ghost of the Gravel is a regional event in Alberta—prairie terrain with moderate elevation. The Alberta prairie is nice and organization is solid, but the moderate access and regional field keep it firmly in Tier 3.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid Alberta prairie gravel race. Worth it for Canadian riders. Not practical for most international riders.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Canada—yes, it's solid. If you're international—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better value: regional gravel races. For similar Canadian terrain: The Range.

logistics.food: Alberta has full dining options. Stock nutrition.
logistics.official_site: Check Ghost of the Gravel website
logistics.camping: Campground to Lyell Saddle hut experienced "a large and unpassable slip" (landslide), forcing route modifications

logistics.explanation: FatBoySlim's race report mentions feed stations at Harold Creek Road and a "last feed station," but specific packet pickup, parking, and lodging details remain absent from available information. The 9:00am start with rollout down Highway 579 is clear, and organizers warn that "portions of the course do not have cell phone coverage" requiring self-sufficiency for emergencies.

length.explanation: The 118km distance creates proper pacing challenges, as FatBoySlim discovered when cramping hit at 77km: "I popped electrolyte tablets in my mouth and started sucking on them to save my life." Hugh McDougall noted it was "full gas from the start" with attacks that "just didn't let up," while Benjamin Perry's winning time of 3:25:43 shows the distance rewards sustained power without crossing into ultra-endurance territory. Longer than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

technicality.explanation: The course features "packed clay gravel with a few sections of looser gravel" through Alberta foothills, requiring attention on Forestry Trunk Road 40's "blind corners." Organizers note this section "has been used as a timed section in Western Canada's Rally West circuit," but the technical demands remain accessible rather than advanced, focusing on power delivery over bike handling skills. Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: The 6,800 feet of climbing peaks at 5,200 feet on Harold Creek Road, where organizers joke riders should "contest your friends on the climb if you know your tank is full, but don't contest the wild horses whom have the true Strava KoM." The climbing creates steady work rather than explosive gradients, though trevorrr warns "the climbs get punchier in the last third, and a lot of people cramp up." Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Weather swings from 25°C heat (FatBoySlim's 2019 experience: "We've only had 1 or 2 days this year of that temperature so I was not really ready for it") to expectations of "5-9 degrees Celsius in rain." Organizers recommend shower caps and full-fingered gloves for summer racing, while arsenalastronaut reported wet conditions that "basically ate thru my chain" and brake pads. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: The 5,200-foot peak elevation at Harold Creek Road sits well below meaningful altitude thresholds for most riders. Starting in Water Valley and climbing through Alberta foothills creates no altitude-related performance impact beyond normal elevation gain workload. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: The course crosses the Little Red Deer river and includes sections where riders encounter wild horses on climbs, with organizers noting these animals hold "the true Strava KoM." Cell coverage gaps require self-sufficiency, and the route traverses ranch valleys through Alberta backcountry, though the adventure feels more like scenic countryside than wilderness exploration.

prestige.explanation: Benjamin Perry's championship victory carried weight: "I've won junior and U23 titles, but I'd never gotten the elite one. I've been dreaming of this for so long." The race hosts Canadian nationals and joins the 2026 UCI Gravel World Series, but field depth remains regional despite championship status, with FatBoySlim finishing 114th place in his 2019 effort.

race_quality.explanation: The course delivers 93% gravel through spectacular foothills terrain, but organizational gaps persist. Feed stations serve perogies and bacon, and the event includes a "full-service BBQ party" finish, yet basic details like cutoff times and precise aid station locations remain unpublished. The racing itself proves intense, with Hugh McDougall noting attacks "from the start" that "just didn't let up."

experience.explanation: The Harold Creek Road climb offers "stunning panoramas" while wild horses provide unexpected trail companions. FatBoySlim's detailed nutrition strategy (6 gels, perogies, bacon at feed stations) and cramping battle at 77km illustrate the self-reliance required. The finish at Water Valley's community hall delivers "exhausted, mud-flecked smiles" and post-race BBQ atmosphere that riders like trevorrr simply call a "great event."

community.explanation: Founded by "a group of friends that loved bikes" who wanted "to make the hardest bike race we could on the coolest roads we knew," the race evolved from the Calgary-to-Calgary Water Valley 220 tradition. Ten years later, organizers note "thousands of starters, winners from 3 different countries" while maintaining feed stations with local perogies and bacon that reflect Alberta gravel culture.

field_depth.explanation: Elite winner Benjamin Perry's 3:25:43 and Masters champion Bruce Bird's 3:50:23 show competitive times, while junior Hugh McDougall's 4th place at 3:58:13 indicates youth participation. However, FatBoySlim's 114th place finish in 2019 suggests limited field size, and the domestic championship status hasn't yet attracted significant international depth. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100. As Benjamin Perry puts it: "I've won junior and U23 titles, but I'd never gotten the elite one. I've been dreaming of this for so long. I'm so proud to be Canadian."

value.explanation: Born from friends who "rode as far and frequently as possible on any bike," the race delivers 110km of gravel through Alberta's best foothills terrain. The experience includes wild horses, river crossings, and a post-race BBQ in historic Water Valley. While entry fees aren't published, the authentic community atmosphere and championship-level course design provide strong experience-to-cost ratio.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $100-150 CAD. Getting to Water Valley, Alberta requires Calgary airport access and unknown lodging arrangements in a small foothills town. The extensive gear recommendations (rain cape, wind jacket, shower cap, full-fingered gloves) reflect the need to prepare for multiple weather scenarios, adding equipment costs. Remote location and international travel requirements inflate total trip expenses beyond the race entry fee. Higher total cost than Badlands.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

videos.title: 2024 Ghost of the Gravel Wrap Up
videos.description:
A smattering of photos from the 2024 Ghost of the Gravel, Canadian Gravel Championships in Water Valley, Alberta. June 16, 2024. 

This video was made with Clipchamp.

Photo credits: Brian Zurek, Bill Quinney, Michele White, Linda Green, Miguel Garcia, Jill Cody, Erin Ruiters, Carthy Chan, Ted Anderson, Cory Wallace, Jeremy Myers, Cody Shimizu (https://www.codyshimizu.com/clients)

Music credit: Ghost of the Gravel by Suno.com

videos.title: The Range Race and Event - 2021 by The Gravel Experience
videos.description: The Range is an Epic Gravel Cycling Event and Race in SW Alberta. The course weaves through the hills on public and private ranch roads providing a premier gravel cycling experience.

videos.title: 2018 Ghost of the Gravel Race presented by Deadgoat racing
videos.description:
Located in Water Valley, the Ghost of the Gravel cycling race has all gravel and none of the traffic. A full-service BBQ party and Red Bull action in the feed zone and start/finish! 
Register at zone4.ca

here are two ghastly flavours to choose from...
The Scary Ghost (118km)
The Friendly Ghost (78km)

The Course:
118 km of scenic and rolling terrain
110 km of continuous gravel
6800 ft. of climbing

More race info: http://deadgoat.ca/ghostofthegravel/

What type of bike should I ride?

Ultimately the choice of steed is up to you, but looking at feedback from last year, here are the bikes you wished your rode:

Road: 3%
Cyclocross: 24%
Gravel: 70%
Mountain: 3%
 
What tires did should I ride?
We know that tires are a fairly personal decision, but again, polling the racers from last year, here's the rankings of rubber for what they wished they had on their hoops:

Road: 3%
Cyclocross: 52%
Gravel: 45%
Mountain: 0%

videos.curation_reason: Best available video with race footage and transcript describing the relaxed atmosphere and terrain in Alberta's foothills.

videos.title: Ghost of the Gravel 2018
videos.description: Highlights from the 118km Gravel race in Water Valley, AB.

quotes.text: I think it's more relaxed you know there's bacon beats here there's cookie stops I think the the super EXTREME like the racing I did for a living for a long time it's like a little bit too aggro for a lot of folks and people are just into like having a good time.

This is awesome great terrain nice Hill great wetter awesome it's just gonna be a lot of fun we're really gonna enjoy a new fake and I'm... I think it'd be cooler on up in the foothills here on the gravel pipe.

terrain_notes.text: Great terrain with nice hills in the foothills area described as awesome with beautiful scenery.

gear_mentions.text: Kona Libre mentioned as a travel bike option for the race.

additional_quotes.text: There's bacon beats here there's cookie stops I think the the super EXTREME like the racing I did for a living for a long time it's like a little bit too aggro for a lot of folks and people are just into like having a good time

rider_intel.search_text: Ghost of the Gravel in Alberta, Canada features terrain in the foothills with nice hills and beautiful scenery. The race has a relaxed atmosphere with bacon beats and cookie stops along the course. Riders describe it as less aggressive than extreme racing, focusing more on having a good time rather than intense competition. The course takes place on gravel roads through the foothills area with awesome terrain that riders find enjoyable. The event appears to emphasize the fun and social aspects of gravel cycling over hardcore racing mentality.
